bibl.note: This is two letters, the first is written by Adam Fergusson, and the second is written on the reverse side, and is dated January 30, 1835 from Louisa C. Jones to Adam Fergusson. In the first letter Fergusson discusses his experiences and good prospects in Mississippi. Jones' letter is an expression of affection and longing to see her sister again.

div1.p: I have just got home from Jackson and Vicksburg and am well pleased with the country and think that I shall be able to get of some time this year the prospects are verry flattering you have stoped in too cold a climate for cotton as is verreyfied by the Early frost last fall I have found many friends in Mississippi that are anxious for me to moove there as a taveron keeper things remain heare just as you left them your friends are all well as fare as I can heare your bacon is in fine order but as yet no chance has offered to send it down nor have I yet learned whare or to what house to send it to but perhaps that can be managed with out any danger of loss we are all well as also our neighbours I shall expect to hear from you as often as convenient
div1.closer:
yours with Mr A Fergusson
Dear Sister I have wated for aletter for som time but have not recieved won from you you must have forgotten the promis you maid when we parted I have been so buisley ingaged at home that I have not had an opportunity I think tharefore I am excusable Oh sister I do mis you and the sweet little children so much, Mother sends hear love to you and Mr Fergusson and the children she often sheds tears a bout them she was very sorry about little willeys misfortunes you must kiss pusse 20 times Willey 10 Charle 5 for heas and tell them they are from thear grand Mother I am in verry low spirits at this time I think if I could see you and the children it would revive me more than any thing else Mother saye she will be out to see you this fall if nothin happens you must write to me as soon as you recieve this I have nothing mor Your Louisa C Jones
Mr Addam Fergusson Legrange Ten mail CARTHAGE Te. JAN 31
